climbs.name: Rumble Strip
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Justin Christiansen, 4 September 2011

content.description:
For lack of a better name, the Camp Wall is just to the right (south and north facing) at the end of the steep road in Monk's Hollow. An old camp with fire ring sits 10m below the climb. 30 second approach time from this old campsite.

The only really prominent black water streak marks the course of the pitch. This conglomerate strip of quite consolidated black colored rock has bands of corrugated cobble that reminded us of the numerous "rumble strips" on highway 6.

Pitch #1: Climb past about 5 glue-in bolts passing one quasi-cruxy move to a two-bolt belay. 5.8, 20m.

climbs.name: Rock And Roll Roadie
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Franziska Garrett, November 2011

content.description:
On the conveniently located shady Rumble Wall to the left of Rumble Strip, this steeper sport climb has pretty good rock.

Pitch #1: Climb the cobbles through some steep and overhanging passages to a two-bolt belay. 5.10b, 20m.

Rappel the route.
content.protection: QDs for (?) 8 bolts to a two-bolt belay.
content.location:
On the so called Rumble Wall just to the left of Rumble Strip, the two routes on this wall are probably some of the better quality conglomerate in this area.

Rappel the route.

content.description: Tower Next to chimney back in the canyon
content.location: Back of monks hollow you wont miss it hard to get to hike up horse trail till u get to bottom then head north east up along the cliff line 3rd class up to the first bolt and go from there (Caution belaying from first bolt may leave you exposed to Rock fall possibly find better place to belay from

climbs.name: Monk
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Quino Gonzales, 24 August 2011

content.description:
Further up the canyon, this is the small conglomerate tower about 50m below the wall with routes coming out of the cave marked by a prominent sandstone band.

This rock is not nearly as good as elsewhere, but a unique tower top. The route ascends the shortest line (north) up the tower. The rappel anchors descend the longest and steepest (south) side of the tower.

Pitch #1: Climb dirty loose cobbles past 3 bolts to an "au cheval" move to the crumbly ridgeline. Pass another bolt to the two-bolt belay. 5.8, 12m.
content.protection: QDs for 4 or 5 bolts. Rappel to the other side descending.
content.location: Walk up the hillside for about 100m to the Monk which stands by itself on the hillside half way to the cave routes.

climbs.name: Horse Cock Tower
climbs.fa: Has been bouldered without bolts for years

content.description: This little climb is pure novelty. The rock is excellent. This super short climb's length is its only draw back, but it seems surreal nonetheless. Remember what they say about a tower being worth more than a wall, and it is to be appreciated for what it is.
content.protection:
One bolt protects this climb, but a #1 Camalot can also be placed at the lip before the mantle move.

A lone bolt is on top for the descent.
content.location: On the left at the entrance of the HC Canyon, it is the smallest of the "towers" and 10 seconds from the dirt road and parked car.

climbs.name: Gumby
climbs.fa: James Garrett, Justin Christiansen, and Jeff Breckenridge, 26 August 2011

content.description:
Walk uphill behind HC Tower to the next tower up and right and approach the downhill and longest side.

Pitch #1: Climb massive cobbles up the broad spine of the Gumby and surmount the crux at its neck to the top of the formation and a three-bolt belay. 5.9, 25m.

Beware of remaining loose cobbles until more traffic cleans it up a bit more. Generally solid rock
content.protection:
Drilled on lead, a few glue-in bolts along with other 3/8" Hilti Wedge and 1/2" Hilti Sleeve bolts were placed.

Helmets recommended for belayer.
content.location: The first "bigger" free standing tower as you enter the canyon. This route ascends the lower angle and slab on the south side.

content.description: Climb starts with a quite tricky first bolt placed into the hard layer of sand stone climb up past first bolt use small smooth cracks to get to second and third after that rock turns into a conglomerate rock once you get about 3\4 the way up the conglomerate rock turns into small rock versus bigger when u start in the conglom. crux is inbetween the last to bolts
content.protection: approx 10 bolts to 2 sets of chains
content.location: once entering monks hollow look at the north west walls and look for a penguin shaped huge rock.  it is directly behind James Garrets free standing tower the Monk
